meanings.definition: Required, permitted, or enacted by statute.
meanings.sent1: The company's policy on breaks is statutory, meaning employees must take them as required by law.
meanings.sent2: The statutory holiday fell on a Monday this year, giving everyone a long weekend.
meanings.sent3: It was quite comical to see the cat's statutory nap time coincide with the postman's daily visit.
meanings.sent4: The statutory warning signs along the road acted as silent guardians, watching over the drivers.
meanings.sent5: The image of the judge holding the statutory book of laws made a lasting impression on the young law students.

meanings.definition: Relating to or created by a statute.
meanings.sent1: The lawyer specialized in handling statutory cases, ensuring all legal requirements were met.
meanings.sent2: The statutory regulations regarding building permits were strictly followed by the construction company.
meanings.sent3: The statutory paperwork seemed to multiply on the desk, creating a colorful paper mountain.
meanings.sent4: Her voice carried a statutory authority that made even the rowdiest of students quiet down.
meanings.sent5: The statutory stamp on the document indicated its official approval by the government.

meanings.definition: Involving or relating to a statute.
meanings.sent1: The judge's decision was based on statutory law, ensuring fairness and consistency.
meanings.sent2: The statutory changes to the tax code affected how businesses reported their earnings.
meanings.sent3: The statutory debate in the courtroom had everyone on the edge of their seats.
meanings.sent4: Her argument had a statutory logic that was hard to refute.
meanings.sent5: The statutory framework provided a solid foundation for the new legal system.
